Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Evolving Topographic Maps with HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=MULOCZxSi_PpRM5Z_V73YCAm_AgVswxvnaJiQhXWtb6rBUlEPLNS

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Sebastian and Ken,

I would like to join the parade of those congratu=
lating you on the interesting work and asking a few minor, technical questi=
ons. I found the work interesting and just want to understand a few small d=
etails better. Here goes:

Are the nodes in the CPPN drawing in Fig. 2 Magi=
c Hat activation nodes? The drawing makes them look like absolute value nod=
es. 
Is it right to characterize the problem in the experiments where you e=
volve the seed as =93Target Weights=94 (i.e. the same problem from [1])? In=
 other words, you give it a specific neural network and its goal is to matc=
h that exact network (though, in this case, after a period of learning/self=
-organization)?
If so, it seems later in the paper that you say that the ta=
rget network it is supposed to match is the one shown in Fig. 3b. Is that r=
ight, or did you challenge it with a different randomly-created target netw=
ork each run?
If you did challenge it with the network in Fig. 3b, then I d=
on=92t get why it takes any time at all for most treatments to evolve this =
pattern. Don=92t you show initially (e.g. Fig. 3) that the seed itself prod=
uces this exact pattern with no further evolution? I apologize if I am miss=
ing something. 
I share Martin=92s question about exactly what is free to e=
volve in the Seeded Uniform treatment. My guess is it is the B to B connect=
ions (i.e. connections from nodes within the output layer to other nodes in=
 the output layer), but I wasn=92t sure.
Finally, why do you think Random d=
oes worse on the test set than the training set? It seems competitive on th=
e training set, just not on the test (i.e. generalization) set. 


Overall,=
 I think it=92s great to see more work on HyperNEAT and learning, and to se=
e a first piece of work on HyperNEAT and SOMs, with a nod toward eventually=
 using HyperNEAT to evolve Deep Networks. Congrats again. 

1. Clune J, Sta=
nley KO, Pennock RT, Ofria C (2011) On the performance of indirect encoding=
 across the continuum of regularity. IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Comp=
utation. 15(3): 346-367. 
pdf: http://goo.gl/qYHPR


Best regards,
Jeff Clu=
ne

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@uw=
yo.edu
jeffclune.com

On May 5, 2014, at 3:10 PM, martin.pyka@... wro=
te:

> Hi Sebastian and Ken,
> 
> 
> congratulations to this paper. As I am=
 looking for a way to use generative and developmenal systems as a tool in =
computational neuroscience, I found your paper very interesting. I also tho=
ught about the possibility to use CPPNs to search for connectivity kernels.=
 And to start with sensory systems makes sense. However, when I understand =
your paper correctly, already the search for a 'mexican hat' turns out to b=
e too deceptive to evolve it from scratch!?
> 
> Now the question is of cou=
rse whether the deceptiveness lies in the fitness function or in the nature=
 of CPPNs. But it is at least discouraging to see that CPPNs cannot easily =
be used in an objective search to evolve networks that we want to see.
> 
>=
 There were two points in your paper that I did not understand. 
> 
> The d=
efinition of the fitness-function (formula 3) implicates that fitness value=
s are between 0-1. But figure 5 and others show values between 0-150. How a=
re these values related to the fitness-function?
> 
> And what changes in a=
n evolutionary run in HyperNEAT with a Seeded Uniform approach. From what I=
 understand, it means that the Seeded part is kept constant, the learning r=
ate is kept constant to 1.0 and the weights from the input to the output ar=
e set to 0.5. So what can be altered in this encoding during an evoluationa=
ry run?
> 
> Best,
> Martin
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_BDA2F73B-D783-4527-A071-0D906BF31369
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252

    <=
div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>Hi Sebastian and Ken,</p><div><br></div><div>congra=
tulations to this paper. As I am looking for a way to use generative and de=
velopmenal systems as a tool in computational neuroscience, I found your pa=
per very interesting. I also thought about the possibility to use CPPNs to =
search for connectivity kernels. And to start with sensory systems makes se=
nse. However, when I understand your paper correctly, already the search fo=
r a 'mexican hat' turns out to be too deceptive to evolve it from scratch!?=
</div><div><br></div><div>Now the question is of course whether the decepti=
veness lies in the fitness function or in the nature of CPPNs. But it is at=
 least discouraging to see that CPPNs cannot easily be used in an objective=
 search to evolve networks that we want to see.</div><div><br></div><div>Th=
ere were two points in your paper that I did not understand. </div><di=
v><br></div><div>The definition of the fitness-function (formula 3) implica=
tes that fitness values are between 0-1. But figure 5 and others show value=
s between 0-150. How are these values related to the fitness-function?</div=
><div><br></div><div>And what changes in an evolutionary run in HyperNEAT w=
ith a Seeded Uniform approach. From what I understand, it means that the Se=
eded part is kept constant, the learning rate is kept constant to 1.0 and t=
he weights from the input to the output are set to 0.5. So what can be alte=
red in this encoding during an evoluationary run?</div><div><br></div><div>=
Best,</div><div>Martin</div><div><br class=3D"webkit-block-placeholder"></d=
iv>

    </div>
     

    

</div>
